subject: RE: [junit] JUnit 4 RFE: expected=name
msgSnippet: Elliotte, I too would prefer not to have to type .class , which seems redundant to me but not, alas, to Java. If you can think of a way to simplify the syntax
messageBody:
Elliotte,

I too would prefer not to have to type ".class", which seems redundant to me but not, alas, to Java. If you can think of a way to simplify the syntax without introducing a preprocessor, please let me know.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Elliotte Harold
> Sent: Friday, September 23, 2005 5:39 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] JUnit 4 RFE: expected=name
>
> I'm not sure if this is possible/plausible with annotations, but I
> thought I'd ask. Here's how we test for an expected exception
> in JUnit 4:
>
> @Test(expected=ArithmeticException.class) public void divideByZero() {
> int n = 2 / 0;
> }
>
> The .class feels superfluous and unnecessary. Why not just:
>
> @Test(expected=ArithmeticException) public void divideByZero() {
> int n = 2 / 0;
> }
>
> Could the framework somehow recognize ArithmeticException as
> the name of
> a class and find the necessary Class object?
>
> The big benefit would simply be cleaner code.
>
> Package issues might make this difficult. I.e. I would not
> want to have
> to type
>
> @Test(expected=java.lang.ArithmeticException) public void
> divideByZero() {
> int n = 2 / 0;
> }
>
>
